text: Is the package jld2 reliable. If I'm able to write and read can it be assured that the data is the same?

elements.text: Is the package jld2 reliable. If I'm able to write and read can it be assured that the data is the same?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
I have used it for several years with no issues. I do not use it to save anything complicated though. I believe it is stable.

elements.text: I have used it for several years with no issues. I do not use it to save anything complicated though. I believe it is stable.

text: I only have array of arrays

elements.text: I only have array of arrays

text: Should be no issues.

elements.text: Should be no issues.

text: Thanks .

elements.text: Thanks .

text: Will JLD eventually be deprecated?

elements.text: Will JLD eventually be deprecated?

text: I have no idea. I am just a user.

elements.text: I have no idea. I am just a user.

text: At this point, JLD and JLD2 have developed into somewhat different packages

elements.text: At this point, JLD and JLD2 have developed into somewhat different packages

text: JLD will likely be around for as long as people are using it and (!) people are willing to maintain it

elements.text: JLD will likely be around for as long as people are using it and (!) people are willing to maintain it

text: What is the difference?

elements.text: What is the difference?

text: The difference is in implementation and performance

elements.text: The difference is in implementation and performance

text: I thought it is only the performance

elements.text: I thought it is only the performance

text:
Both are based on the `HDF5` format.
`JLD` uses the `HDF5` c library and `JLD2` implements (a subset of ) the HDF5 standard.
This allows for very significant performance improvements

elements.text: Both are based on the
HDF5
format.
JLD
uses the
HDF5
c library and
JLD2

implements (a subset of ) the HDF5 standard.
This allows for very significant performance improvements

text:
However it also increases the complexity of the code base considerably.
Additionally it make maintenance of the package much harder.

elements.text:
However it also increases the complexity of the code base considerably.
Additionally it make maintenance of the package much harder.

text: So JLD2 is pure Julia?

elements.text: So JLD2 is pure Julia?

text: I write sceintific paper. Can I trust the results plotted from jld2 writers file?

elements.text: I write sceintific paper. Can I trust the results plotted from jld2 writers file?

text: JLD2 is pure Julia and yes, you should be able to trust the results

elements.text: JLD2 is pure Julia and yes, you should be able to trust the results

text:
Of course, you should always employ common sense when it comes to results.
But in the last few years there were no real problems with JLD2 returning "wrong" data

elements.text:
Of course, you should always employ common sense when it comes to results.

text: Thanks

elements.text: Thanks

text:
I happen to be the maintainer of JLD2.
If you have further questions, feel free to open an issue on the github page.
